msgSnippet: Mike, If you only use your own tag libraries then you should have no problem running JSPs with mock objects, although there are quite a few interfaces to
messageBody:
Mike,
 
If you only use your own tag libraries then you should have no problem running JSPs with mock objects, although there are quite a few interfaces to implement.
 
We use a small set of custom tags extensively to a give us a look and feel on all our pages.  We don't seem to have found any performance problems.  My only advise here is that if you are using weblogic then it's best to manually remove references to beans from the request and response scope after a page has been generated, or they won't be garbage collected.  But think I am starting to go off-topic...
 
One approach that can be used is to implement the RequestDispatcher of your mock Servlet container such that when you can intercept forwards and includes.  This way you can assert that the Servlet has added the correct beans to the request so that the JSP can render the correct view.
 
Dave
-----Original Message-----
From: Mike Duffy [mailto:mike.duffy@...]
Sent: 18 June 2001 16:46
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Has someone done Servlet JUnit tests?

Yes, keeping servlets and JSPs as thin as possible is a good approach.

Is anyone aware of any problems with the implementation of JSP tag libraries on the various application servers?

Also, is there any significant hit to performance when using tag libraries?

Mike



Paul Hodgetts wrote:

> Peter Qi wrote:
>
>  > I need to create some JUnit tests for a Servlet.  But because the
>  > doGet(HttpServletRequest, HttpServletResponse) and
>  > doPost(HttpServletRequest, HttpServletResponse) methods have no returns,
>  > and HttpServletRequest and HttpServletResponse are generated by the
>  > system, I could not create JUnit tests for them.  Does anyone have some
>  > experience?  Thanks a lot for the help.
>
> You can use HTTPUnit to run tests against the servlet.  The
> problem, however, as you point out, is that you only have
> limited visibility into the servlet, since you can only check
> the returned HTTP response to the web client.  It's gets even
> more fun when you're trying to test the behavior of session
> time outs, security and log in checks, etc.
>
> What we've discussed doing is to make our servlets (and JSPs
> via tag libraries) very thin layers that take the incoming
> requests and just delegate to our presentation helper classes.
> In many cases, we'll end up just passing the request and
> session objects along, but we now have a point where we can
> create the request or session objects in particular states
> (like expired session), so we can much more easily test the
> interface's behavior, plus we can use JUnit.
>
> This isn't a silver bullet or anything, because there are
> still cases where you want to test the actual returned HTML,
> and sometimes HTTPUnit tests are the best way to do that.
> But it seems like it will make our life a bit easier for some
> other classes of presentation layer testing.
>
> Anyone else try this?
>
> -Paul Hodgetts
